position.marginalia_text: Item, videmus nubem pluviale[m] virtute Caloru[m] sursum ascendere: et co[n]tra naturam sua[m] elevari (Nam Aqua de natura sua semper deorsum petit, tanq[uam] grave) et cum venit ad locu[m] perpetui frigoris, in quo frigiditas superat caliditate[m], tunc Nubes convertitur in Aqua[m]: virtute sua frigiditatis inspissantis, & convertentis substa[n]tia[m] nubis in Aqua[m], et ita generatur pluvia. Et etia[m] cu[m] ventus [etc]

marginalia.translation: Also, we see that the rain clouds rise high by virute of heat and against their nature are lifted up. (For water, according to its nature, always strives downwards, heavy as it is) And when it comes to the place of continuous cold, in which coldness surpasses heat, then the clouds are turned into water by the virtue of the cold, which condenses and reverses the substancve of the cloud into water. Thus rain is generated. And also when the wind etc.

position.marginalia_text: Et qua[e] forma est illa? Certe corporis corrupti, quod vocatur a sapientibus huius artis Saturnus, vel plumbu[m], vel a[e]s, propter sua[m] nigredinem, et immmunditia[m] a qua nigre[dine]

marginalia.translation: And of what shape is it? Certainly that of a corupt body, which the wise of this art call Saturn or lead or air for its blackness and dirtiness. From this blackness [...]
